title: Protocol to analyze the inhibitory effect of free organic carbon generated by chemoautotrophic bacteria on their CO2 fixation
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Part 1: Comparison of total organic carbon yield in the membrane reactor and conventional reactor to explore the effect of EFOC on bacterial CO2 fixation
Timing: 14 days
It is reported that self-generated extracellular free organic carbon (EFOC) has an inhibitory effect on bacterial carbon fixation by chemoautotrophic bacteria.6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6] We designed comparative experiments of total carbon fixation yield in a conventional reactor and a membrane reactor, which can filter EFOC with a membrane module, to explore the effect of self-generated EFOC on CO2 fixation of chemoautotrophic bacteria.
Prepare a membrane reactor system and a conventional reactor system.
Make three two-layer flat membrane modules (length 6 cm × width 1 cm × height 8 cm) with 0.22 μm PVDF/PTFE membrane.
Note: Replace the membrane module with a clean module when it becomes seriously fouled during reactor operating, so it is necessary to prepare several membrane modules for backup. Must check the tightness of the membrane module before use it.
Make two 2 L lab-scale reactor using plexiglass (bioreactor size: diameter 16 cm × height 16 cm) (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]) for assemble membrane reactor system and conventional reactor system. Clean the reactor and pipes using sterile water and sterilize them under UV conditions.
Assemble the reactor, aeration equipment, peristaltic pump, stirring equipment, inlet pipe, outlet pipe, fresh medium storage tank and effluent storage tank to form a membrane reactor system (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Note: The inlet pipe and outlet pipe are peristaltic pump packages that do not require researchers to make additional purchases. Just use ordinary sterilized containers as the fresh medium storage tank and effluent storage tank.
Set up a conventional reactor with no flat membrane at the same time (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Inoculate and cultivate bacteria in reactors before turning on the peristaltic pump.

Prepare 4 L sterile optimum inorganic medium of DSM 505 according to the DSMZ THIOBACILLUS MEDIUM (https://www.dsmz.de/microorganisms/medium/pdf/DSMZ_Medium36.pdf[href=https://www.dsmz.de/microorganisms/medium/pdf/DSMZ_Medium36.pdf]). Additionally add 0.75 g/L Na2CO3 and 0.75 g/L NaHCO3 to the medium to maintain enough carbon sources.
Pour 2 L of the sterile mixed medium into membrane reactor, conventional reactor and fresh medium storage tank separately.
Seed 100 mL bacteria at the logarithmic phase into the medium of membrane reactor and the medium of conventional reactor.
Turn on the power of the magnetic stirrer with a stirring speed of over 200 rpm.
Turn on the power of air pumps to supply air into both reactors with an aeration rate of 1 L/min in order to supply CO2 and O2 as carbon source and electron acceptor.
Note: Adjust the inoculation volume according to volume of reactor, but the inoculation ratio of 5% (V/V) is recommended. The rotational speed of magnetic stirring rotors should enable the good mixing of the medium in reactors. Researchers should increase the aeration flow when the reactor is designed for a larger volume.
Incubate bacteria for 3 days at 28°C.
Note: This incubation allows the bacteria to adapt to reactor and become metabolically active. If researchers choose different chemoautotrophic bacteria, researchers should shorten or lengthen this incubation time according to the generation time.
Reactor system set up.
For the membrane reactor system, turn on two peristaltic pumps to flow sterile fresh medium of DSM 505 into the membrane reactor with a flow rate of 1 L/day and filter the liquid out of the reactor through the membrane module at a flow rate of 1 L/day.
For the conventional reactor system, add 20 mL of culture medium concentrate (25-fold) once every 3 days to maintain enough energy and carbon sources.

Note: Add 0.75 g/L Na2CO3 and 0.75 g/L NaHCO3 into the sterile fresh medium to maintain enough carbon source. The inflow rate and outflow rate are same. Adjust the inflow rate and outflow rate according to bacterial generation time. Add 25 times the amount of the components in the DSMZ THIOBACILLUS MEDIUM (https://www.dsmz.de/microorganisms/medium/pdf/DSMZ_Medium36.pdf[href=https://www.dsmz.de/microorganisms/medium/pdf/DSMZ_Medium36.pdf]) , except distilled water, into 1 L distilled water to obtain culture medium concentrate (25-fold).
Operate the membrane reactor system and the conventional reactor system for 11 days. During the operation period, adjust pH in both reactors to 5.0–7.0 with 1.0 M NaOH and collect suitable volume of bacterial solution every day for next experiments.

Determinate total organic carbon (TOC) yield fixed by DSM 505.

Note: The volume of bacterial solution for TOC determination should meet the minimum detection volume of the instrument. Make sure the TOC bottle is cleaned and not contaminated with organic matter.
Add an appropriate volume of concentrated hydrochloric acid to adjust the pH to about 4.
Note: The addition of hydrochloric acid to adjust pH to acidity is to exclude the influence of inorganic carbon.

Part 2: Analysis of the inhibition effect of self-generated EFOC on bacterial CO2 fixation with simulation experiment
Timing: 5 days
In this section, we separate and obtain EFOC generated by DSM 505 and add different concentrations of the EFOC into the culture medium during bacterial cultivation to analyze the effects of self-generated EFOC on bacterial CO2 fixation.
Obtain concentrated EFOC generated by DSM 505.
Autotrophically cultivate DSM 505 for 3 days to make sure the bacterial TOC reach 10 mg C/L for the next EFOC obtain steps.
Note: The chemoautotrophic cultivation steps is same as the steps of microbial culture in the “before you begin[href=https://www.wicell.org#before-you-begin]” section. To emphasize the differences, the experiments below are focused on the different procedures and simplify the same procedures.
Collect whole bacterial solution of DSM 505 after 3 days of chemoautotrophic culture.
Filter the bacterial solution with a 0.22-μm water filter membrane to obtain EFOC solution.
Treat EFOC solution with dialysis tubing (MD34-300D-01) to remove inorganic salts.
Note: Use deionized water as dialysis solution and regularly replace the distilled water outside the dialysis tubing. Determine the conductivity of EFOC solution to indicate the inorganic salt content. When the conductivity of solution is less than or equal to 10 μs/cm, the solution is considered almost free of inorganic salts.
Freeze dry and concentrate the EFOC with −55°C for 24–48 h to obtain EFOC with concentration above 15 mg C/L.
Prepare the sterile chemoautotrophic medium of DSM 505 according to the DSMZ THIOBACILLUS MEDIUM (https://www.dsmz.de/microorganisms/medium/pdf/DSMZ_Medium36.pdf[href=https://www.dsmz.de/microorganisms/medium/pdf/DSMZ_Medium36.pdf]).

Prepare 2 L the optimum inorganic medium of DSM 505.
Fill a 150 mL serum bottle with 40 mL of the inorganic medium and then autoclave the serum bottle at 120°C for 20 min.
Allow the sterilized medium to cool down to room temperature.
Add the concentrated EFOC into two 150 mL serum bottles with 40 mL sterile inorganic medium to achieve two different concentrations, low (3.83 mg C/L) and high (8.15 mg C/L). Add the 150 mL serum bottle with 40 mL sterile inorganic medium with no addition of EFOC as negative control group (CK).
Note: The EFOC generated by DSM 505 is distributed approximately in the range of 2 mg C/L to 15 mg C/L, so we designed low and high concentrations of EFOC. Set up three parallel bottles for each group.
Inoculate bacteria and set cultivation conditions.
Add 1 mL of bacteria solution (with an initial inoculation concentration of 1.5 mg/L TOC) into every 150 mL serum bottle and seal the bottle with a sterilized silicon stopper.
Fill in the bottles with 10% CO2 and 21% O2 to supply the inorganic carbon source and electron donor.
Seal with parafilm on the outside of the stopper.
Place all bottles on a shaking table at 28°C and 120 rpm.
Continuously incubate bacteria for 168 h and collect bacterial solution samples at 24 h, 72 h, and 168 h for subsequent determinations.
Critical: Carried out all above manipulations in this part under strict aseptic conditions and all solutions should be sterile.
Determinate total organic carbon (TOC) yield of the collected samples.
Note: The steps of determination of TOC are roughly similar. To emphasize the differences, the experiments below are focused on the different procedures and simplify the same procedures.

Extract DNA, extract RNA, synthesis cDNA, and detect gene abundance and transcription level of cbb genes with qRT-PCR.
Note: The detailed steps of DNA extraction, RNA extraction, cDNA synthesis, and qRT-PCR detection are systematic and numerous, so those steps are presented as a separate part, and please refer to the section “DNA extraction, RNA extraction, cDNA synthesis, and qRT-PCR detection”.
Part 3: Analysis of main inhibitory components in EFOC self-generated by chemoautotrophic bacteria with chromatography and correlation analysis
Timing: 10 days
To further clarify the inhibitory components of EFOC, the molecular weight (MW) distribution, molecular and compositional diversity of small-molecule EFOC generated by DSM 505 are determined with gel filtration chromatography and liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry.
Obtain EFOC from different cultivation stages.
Autotrophically cultivate DSM 505 for 9 days.
Collect bacterial solution samples at early stage (day 3), middle stage (day 6) and late stage (day 9) separately for the determination of MW distribution and TOC yield separately.
Note: The specific time points for early stage, middle stage, and late stage of cultivation depends on the experiment requirements and bacterial generation time. Every data point is performed in biological triplicates.
Filter the bacterial solutions of different stages with 0.22-μm water filter membrane to obtain EFOC of different stages separately.
Determinate the TOC yield and EFOC yield with TOC-L analyzer.
Determinate MW distribution of EFOC.
Filter 1.5 mL EFOC with 0.2-μm membrane into a clean chromatography autosampler vial.
Place the vials on the gel filtration chromatography (LC-20AD).
Set up and run the gel filtration chromatography instrument.
Note: Present the settings of gel filtration chromatography with the following format.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2673_3.csv
Analyze the Bivariate correlations relationships between the proportion and concentration of small-molecule EFOC and large-molecule EFOC and the apparent CO2 fixation efficiency with the SPSS 20.0 statistical analysis software (IBM, Armonk, NY, USA).

Assay the composition of small-molecule EFOC.
Note: Our studies shows that the removal of EFOC generated by chemoautotrophic bacterium, especially the release of small-molecule EFOC, promoted the bacterial carbon fixation.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7] Besides, the negative correlation between CO2 fixation efficiency and the proportion of small-molecule EFOC is significant, which indicating small-molecule EFOC is the main inhibitory.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1] Therefore, the composition small-molecule EFOC is assayed to clarify the inhibitory composition. Researchers can narrow down the molecular weight range of EFOC for component analysis based on previous research results.
Collect bacterial solution samples at the early stage (day 2), middle stage (day 4), and late stage (day 8) during autotrophic cultivation respectively.
Filter the samples through 0.22-μm sterile membranes.
Set up and run the liquid chromatography–mass spectrometry.

Part 4: Verification of the effect of main inhibitory components in EFOC on CO2 fixation by simulation experiment and investigate its mechanism from view of genes transcription
Timing: 8 days
In order to evaluate the inhibitory effect of the main inhibitory components of EFOC on CO2 fixation by chemoautotrophic bacteria, we calculate the carbon fixation yield and the abundance and transcription level of ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RuBisCO) genes (cbb) of bacteria that cultured with different inhibitory components at the same concentration.
Prepare sterile free organic carbon stock solution.
Prepare a 400 mg carbon [C]/L L-alanine stock solution by adding 100 mg L-alanine into 100 mL deionized water.
Prepare a 400 mg C/L fructose stock solution by adding 100 mg fructose into 100 mL deionized water.
Prepare a 400 mg C/L L-aspartic acid stock solution by adding 111 mg fructose into 100 mL deionized water.

Prepare a 400 mg C/L oxaloacetic acid stock solution by adding 112 mg oxaloacetic acid into 100 mL deionized water.
Prepare a 400 mg C/L bovine albumin stock solution by adding 80 mg bovine albumin into 100 mL deionized water.
Filter the L-alanine stock solution, fructose stock solution, L-aspartic acid stock solution, oxaloacetic acid stock solution, bovine albumin stock solution using a sterile syringe with a 0.22 μm sterile filter, separately.
Note: Store the free organic carbon stock solution in sterile sealed Erlenmeyer flask at 4°C for short-term storage.
Prepare the sterilized optimum inorganic medium of DSM 505 according to the DSMZ THIOBACILLUS MEDIUM (https://www.dsmz.de/microorganisms/medium/pdf/DSMZ_Medium36.pdf[href=https://www.dsmz.de/microorganisms/medium/pdf/DSMZ_Medium36.pdf]).
Prepare 2 L the optimum inorganic medium of DSM 505.
Fill a 150 mL serum bottle with 60 mL of the inorganic medium and then autoclave the serum bottle at 120°C for 20 min.
Allow the sterilized medium to cool down to room temperature.
Inoculate the bacteria and set cultivation conditions.
Add 1.5 mL one type of the organic stock solutions into the 150 mL serum bottle with 60 mL sterilized medium to prepare 10 mg C/L organic condition, separately.
Note: For example, add 1.5 mL fructose concentrate into the 150 mL serum bottle with 60 mL sterilized medium in order to prepare a 10 mg C/L fructose condition.
Add 1.572 μL pyruvate stock solution with mass percentage of 98.5% into the 150 mL serum bottle with 60 mL sterilized medium to prepare 10 mg C/L pyruvate condition.
Inoculate 1.5 mL bacteria solution with an initial inoculation concentration of 1.5 mg/L total organic carbon into 150 mL serum bottle at 2.5% (V/V) and seal the bottles with sterilized silicon stoppers.
Note: Adjust the volume of sterilized medium according to the experiment and an inoculation ratio of 2.5% (V/V) is recommended.

A control group with no added concentrate is also set up simultaneously. Four duplicate bottles are set for each condition.
Note: Set each condition in biological triplicates, and it should always include a control.
Fill in a bottle with 10% CO2 and 21% O2 and seal with parafilm on the outside of the stopper. Place all bottles on a shaking table at 28°C and 120 rpm.
Cultivate bacteria for 7 days and collect bacterial solution samples at early, middle and late stages for subsequent experimental analysis.
Determinate total organic carbon (TOC) yield of the collected samples. Calculate the bacterial net carbon fixation yield: TOCNet = TOCfinal-TOCinitial.
Extract DNA, extract RNA, synthesis cDNA, and detect gene abundance and transcription level of cbb genes with qRT-PCR.
DNA extraction, RNA extraction, cDNA synthesis, and qRT-PCR detection
Timing: 2 days
The ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RuBisCO) gene (cbb) transcription is a key reaction for CO2 assimilation mediated by chemoautotrophic bacteria.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8],9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9],10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10],11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11] At this section, bacteria are collected for DNA extraction, RNA extraction and then cDNA is synthesized. The DNA and cDNA are prepared for subsequent qPCR detection of cbb gene abundance and transcription level.
Collect 15–20 mL bacterial solution samples during cultivation, and filter samples through sterile 0.22 μm membranes with sterile 20 mL syringes to collect bacterial cells.
Note: Adjust the sampling volume according to the actual growth of bacteria to collect enough cell for nucleic acid extraction.
Collect a membrane capturing bacterial cells into a PowerBead Pro Tube provided by DNeasy PowerSoil Pro Kit for DNA extraction.
Add Solution CD1, Solution CD2, Solution CD3, Solution EA, Solution C5 and 50 μL of DNase-free ddH2O to extract, purify and obtain DNA according to the manufacturer’s instruction (https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=9bb59b74-e493-4aeb-b6c1-f660852e8d97&lang=en[href=https://www.qiagen.com/us/resources/resourcedetail?id=9bb59b74-e493-4aeb-b6c1-f660852e8d97&lang=en]).

Note: The protocol shown here is for the DNeasy PowerSoil Pro Kit following the manufacturer’s instructions (QIAGEN, Germany). Researchers can use other DNA isolation kits and should follow the respective manufacturer’s protocol.
Collect the membrane containing bacterial cells into a 1.5 mL RNase-free Microcentrifuge Tube for RNA extraction.
Add 1 mL RNAiso Plus into the RNase-free Microcentrifuge Tube. Place the tube in FastPrep-24 and shake for 30 s to disrupt the cells. Then place the tube on ice for 40–60 min.
Centrifuge at 12,000 × g for 15 min at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant to a clean 1.5 mL RNase-free Microcentrifuge Tube, add 0.2 mL of chloroform per 1 mL of TRIzol, and shake vigorously manually for 15 s.
Incubate cells in the tube for 2–3 min at room temperature. And then centrifuge at 12,000 × g for 20 min at 4°C. Transfer the entire colorless aqueous layer into a clean RNase-free Microcentrifuge Tube.
Note: After centrifugation, the mixture is divided into 3 layers, a red phenol-chloroform layer, a middle layer, and a colorless aqueous layer containing RNA.
Add the same volume of 70% (V/V) alcohol as the volume of colorless aqueous layer and mix well by vortex shaking. Turn upside down to dissolve the precipitate formed after adding alcohol.
Proceed to Binding, Washing, and Elution with Spin Cartridge, Wash Buffer I, Wash Buffer II and 30 μL RNase-Free Water to extract, purify and obtain RNA according to the manufacturer’s instruction (https://www.thermofisher.cn/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.cn/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fpurelink_rna_mini_kit_man.pdf[href=https://www.thermofisher.cn/document-connect/document-connect.html?url=https://assets.thermofisher.cn/TFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fpurelink_rna_mini_kit_man.pdf]).
Note: The protocol shown here is for the PureLinkTM RNA Mini Kit following the manufacturer’s instructions (Invitrogen, USA). Researchers can use other RNA isolation kits and should follow the respective manufacturer’s protocol.
Eliminate genomic DNA contamination and fast synthesis cDNA using PrimeScript™ RT reagent Kit with gDNA Eraser (Perfect Real time) (https://www.takarabio.com/documents/User%20Manual/RR047A/RR047A_UM.pdf[href=https://www.takarabio.com/documents/User%20Manual/RR047A/RR047A_UM.pdf]).
Genomic DNA elimination reaction.

Prepare a master mix for components other than the RNA sample in a volume enough for the number of reactions plus 2 to compensate for the liquid loss during pipetting.

Critical: If the total RNA concentration < 142 ng/μL, researchers can directly use it for genomic DNA elimination reaction master mix. If the RNA concentration > 142 ng/μL, researchers need to dilute it with DEPC water.
Dispense an appropriate volume of master mix (total volume minus total RNA volume) into a sterile, nuclease-free 0.2 mL microtube and then add the RNA sample. Mix gently, centrifuge briefly and incubate at 42°C for 2 min.

Add 10 μL of master mix to the reaction solution from genomic DNA elimination reaction and then mix gently and centrifuge briefly.

Proceed immediately with the reverse-transcription reaction. Incubate for 15 min at 37°C, followed by 5 s at 85°C and terminate the reaction at 4°C.

Note: Prepare the 1.2 times of premix volume needed because of the liquid loss during pipetting. Present PCR reaction master mix with the following format.

Mix thoroughly, and then centrifuge briefly to spin down the liquid and eliminate any air bubbles. Transfer 20 μL each reaction to each well of 96-well plate.
Set up and run the qRT-PCR instrument.
Place the 96-well plate in the qRT-PCR instrument correctly.
Set the thermal cycling conditions according to the instrument cycling parameters, manufacturer’s instruction of qPCR mixture and melting temperatures of the specific primers.
